qas.question: How long has Proportionality been recognized as one of the general principles of EU law?
Where is the principle of proportionality recognized in the EC treaty?

answers.text: the lawfulness of an action depends on whether it was appropriate and necessary to achieve the objectives legitimately pursued

qas.question: Which measure must be adopted when there is a choice between several?

answers.text: the least onerous must be adopted
the least onerous must be adopted

qas.question: How long has Proportionality not been recognized as one of the general principles of Eu law?

plausible_answers.text: whether it was appropriate and necessary to achieve the objectives legitimately pursued

qas.question: What does the lawfulness of action not depend on?
Which measure is adopted when there is a choice between several inappropriate measures?
Where is the principle of proportionality not recognized in the EC treaty?

plausible_answers.text: that "any action by the Community shall not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of this Treaty

qas.question: What is not stated in Article 5 of the EC Treaty?

context: Proportionality is recognised one of the general principles of European Union law by the European Court of Justice <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b3_0>since the 1950s<b3_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. According to the general principle of proportionality <a1_1>the lawfulness of an action depends on <b4_0>whether it was appropriate and necessary to achieve the objectives legitimately pursued<b4_0/><a1_1/>. When there is a choice between several appropriate measures <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b5_0>the least onerous<b5_0/><a2_0/> must be adopted<a2_2/><a2_1/>, and any disadvantage caused must not be disproportionate to the aims pursued. The principle of proportionality is also recognised <a1_0><b6_0>in <a1_2>Article 5<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_0/> of the EC Treaty, stating <b7_0>that "any action by the Community shall not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of this Treaty<b7_0/>".
